txt: I identify as male
I identify as female
I identify as Pakeha/European
I identify as Pasifika
I identify as Maori
I identify as Asian
I live in a city
I am a parent
I am or have been overweight
The sugar and obesity problem needs to be addressed fairly urgently.
The rapid rise of obesity is also about changes in the way we live as a society and in what we eat so we need to address a range of these matters
Current initiatives aim to encourage individuals to lead healthier lifestyles and the food and beverage industry to voluntarily provide healthier products and consumer information.
Individuals should be free to decide whether and to what extent they consume products with high levels of sugar as long as they don’t harm others.
We only need policies which a focus on preventing harm to others, not self-harm
People should be responsible for their making their own decisions about what and how much they eat and drink as long as accurate information and appropriate education is provided.
The government should not limit an individual’s freedom to choose unless those choices are seriously harming others.
The significant increase in sugar in food and drinks is there to make food and drink more appealing and addictive hence increase sales revenue.
We should ban or restrict the marketing of sugary drinks and food to children and teenagers.
We need to invest in better information and education about the health impacts of sugar
We should regulate the food and beverage industry to force them to lower the amount of sugar in food and drinks
The NZ government needs to act much more boldly and with much more urgency.
Reducing the intake of sugar should be Government policy goal - especially for children and teenagers.
We should use food taxes and subsidies to encourage the consumption of health food and discourage the consumption of unhealthy foods
We should impose restrictions on junk food marketing, particularly to children
We should impose a ban on point of sale promotion of high sugar items in supermarkets
We should make sure that people can afford healthy food and drinks and families have enough time to prepare healthy meals.
interventions need to go beyond the regulation of sugar and address the drivers of inequality.
Interventions must be developed in collaboration with communities so that they are effective and take their interests into account
The Treaty of Waitangi makes clear references to Māori health and places obligations on the Crown to protect Māori and their health.
The Crown also has a duty to ensure Maori health protection measures are done in partnership with Māori.
If healthier foods were cheaper i would eat them more
It is unfair to financially harm low income people, especially Māori, by using taxes to increase the price of food and drink
Encourage Māori to set up māra kai (vegetable gardens) and teach gardening and cooking skills with a wider range of healthier methods
Support Māori educational achievement which correlates with better diets and better health.

Current initiatives aiming to encourage individuals to lead healthier lifestyles and the food and beverage industry to voluntarily provide healthier products and consumer information are sufficient - we do not need to regulate.
Resource programs which enable young people to grow and create their own food and understand the science behind how it all works.
We should place tighter restrictions on advertising sugary drinks and junk foods, especially to kids.
The "obesity epidemic" is unscientific nonsense. Discussions starting from "being fat is unhealthy" only encourage bias against fat people
Sugar taxes only make it harder for families who already can't make ends meet. Don't punish poor people.
Sugar taxes don't harm manufacturers, they harm consumers. Give people money & time & less stress and they'll be healthier.
Redesign our obesogenic environment to make walking and cycling easy and attractive. Improve footpaths & cyclepaths & lower traffic speeds.
It is difficult to say give people autonomy to decide with no regulation when society has to pay in the health care costs of obesity.
The govt MUST impose a sugar tax on all artificially sweetened & fizzy drinks reducing the social and economic cost of obesity illnesses.
Other countries impose sugar tax - we MUST follow to stop childhood  obesity in this country!
Sugar needs to be regulated and taxed.
Unwilling to add more complicated taxes, better to label harshly and educate, perhaps restrict sale to under 15 year olds
I think that subsidizing Healthy fresh foods would help offset the negative effects of taxing sugary foods.
Free public pools, exercise equipment in public places and programs aimed at fitness would make a huge difference. energy in = energy out
Taxing Unhealthy foods is fair as it reflects there drain on the public health system.
I would prioritise subsidising healthy foods over taxing unhealthy foods.
People will feed themselves properly if the can afford to. Make good food cheaper.
People will feed themselves properly if they can afford to. Give people more money.
When families are financially-poor, both parents work yet still struggle to pay bills, why should we expect these families to be time-rich?
Your comment 'Invest in better information and education about the health impacts of sugar' is too loose.
We need to educate children before they get bitten by the 'sugar bug'. They can influence their parents, similar to  the Quitprogramme.
I actively avoid sugary food
sugar is rapidly converted to fat
I never buy fizzy drink
Higher tax on high sugar foods, which can then be used to subsidise the rediculous cost of healthy foods like fruit, vegetables and meat!!!
Legislation to provide drinking water fountains at all schools from early childhood to high schools.
Special much higher tax category for manufacturers and sellers of sugar drinks.
Honestly! Being fat seems to be on a par with the dangers of global warming. "Othering" isnt helpful!
Money from sugar taxes could also be used to support local social clubs(rugby,running, sailing etc) to give people more options to be active
Fresh, good quality NZ produce should be more affordable to buy in NZ than overseas.
Milk prices jumped up in 2001 when the Govt allowed Fonterra to form thereby reducing domestic competition. (Threaten to) Regulate the price
The Govt should work with the food & beverage industry to make NZ a global leader in solving obesity via new products & marketing approaches
Regulation, or the threat of it, should be used to drive and direct innovation in the food and beverage industry towards healthier products
Regulation through central and local government is needed to stop the endless creation of food deserts in low socio-economic areas
I would like to see a tax on sugary drinks with >2% free sugars but NOT on artificially sweetened drink with less than 2% free sugars
The media should stop linking obesity with sugar. Poverty and stress are much bigger drivers in the obesity problem.
Media should play its part in challenging consumerist attitudes In our society.
If manufacturers can't address the price imbalance between unhealthy food and healthy food (e.g. Soda vs Milk), then taxation has to do it.
If "enlightened self-interest" worked, manufacturers would already have acted for the long-term good of their customers.
NZ should also provide tax/import-duty breaks for healthy sugar substitutes, eg stevia
Also need  better education in schools on metabolic diseases such as type-2 diabetes and its links to obesity and lack of exercise.
Schools/communities should be taught NZ-specific  genetic issues such as higher obesity/diabetes risk for descendants of Polynesian voyagers
Nothing is ever simple and approaching the issues from a single perspective i.e chose from one of the options(?)seems to be a weakness
Need to regulate the amount of sugar in baby/toddler foods so that children aren't habituated to mainly eating sweet foods from birth
We should provide a simple information system such as traffic light to indicate quantity and type of sugar
In general, those that are hit hardest by progressive taxation will be those whose health will benefit the most.
The cost of diabetes will be $1.8 billion by 2021. This should be taken into account when lack of harm to others is being considered.
It takes a well-adjusted non-needy person to eat well.
People frequently overeat to fill the emotional “black hole” in their psyche. It goes much deeper than self-control.
The lack of focus by mainstream medical experts and the media on the importance of psychological health in obesity is disappointing.
The lack of focus by mainstream medical experts on the importance of psychological health in obesity is disappointing.
Medicalising obesity doesn’t do justice to the complexity of the issues involved. A good sense of self-esteem and self-worth are important too.
There are many factors that citrine to our obesity epidemic. The solution needs to be social nor individual.
A Traffic light sugar warning system won't work as there are many types of sugars which are present in ratio's. Manufacturers use this fact.
Most of the interventions won't work well as we use sugar for psychological & cultural reasons. Sugar is a comfort, a pick-me-up, a treat
We need large scale marketing campaigns to change the way people think about and consume sugary products
Supplement regulation with a stronger emphasis on food supply - quality and economy.
teach children self control and not to be greedy.
Fresh vegetables are a luxury for many new zealanders
Supermarket layouts strongly influence peoples' food purchases.
Take GST off healthy basic foods, that put 15% back into pockets immediately making good food more attractive,
Something is wrong when 'pop' is cheaper than water or milk.
Sugar labelled in teaspoons is a better method of labeling
Corn syrup is worse because it is cheap but a slightly different chemical make up
educate, don't regulate
My opinion on the food industry is, comparable to the cigarette companies using nicotine to attract people smoking as to sugar does for food
We need a 'sugar equivalent' indicator on labelling to account for effects of different types of sugar
Education alone isn't good enough as no one can everything. Regulation ensures that everyone is working to the same, up to date information.
We tax tobacco to cover health costs, we should tax sugar to do the same.
I think all companies that add sugar to their product lines need to show this as "spoonfuls of sugar added" This way a customer can choose.

The government should adopt the 7 actions of the New Zealand Dentists Association 'Consensus statement on Sugary drinks' as outlined here: 
http://www.healthysmiles.org.nz/assets/pdf/Consensus%20Statement%20on%20Sugary%20Drinks.pdf
Not addressing obesity, is a major missed opportunity.
Letting food manufacturers sell food laced with fat, salt and sugar, is like letting people build houses without toilets
Relying on education & individual choice when it comes to sugar will only worsen disparities in life & health outcomes
Sugar in food is addictive and used for comfort, also its an useful preservative our food, unlike Tabacco it is EVERYWHERE...
...Anti Tabacco was successful through ads (educate), heavy taxes (punish), available cheap healthcare (support)
Any legislation of sugar should be backed up by scientific evidence or studies of effects of similar legislation in other parts of the world
Taxing sugar is all well and good, and I agree as long as the alternative is made cheaper. Drop GST on fresh fruit and veges.
Not only should we subsidize fruit & veg but take steps to ensure a range of providers of local produce in every community
